title: Thursday, 15th March, 2018
bodyHTML:
11:02 am

J L Morning
Badger Morning All

This is Markets Live, FT Alphavilelsdfad; adfgadfg.

GBKrona Hola

Fair amount of news today!

I mean, war. Obv. There's war.

JuB Yo

sprout that's not quite fair. Humphrey's asked him if a return to the old style Cold War stand off was likely and Boris said 'no'

wayneJ Morning

11:06 am
BE11:06am

Theranos, CEO Holmes, and Former President Balwani Charged With Massive Fraud
Holmes Stripped of Control of Company for Defrauding Investors
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
2018-41

Washington D.C., March 14, 2018 ....

JuB robert palmer simply irresistable ... they dont make em like him anymore
Manxish Morning
Miss Piggy Boris would start a war just to be PM, the scoundrel.
BE11:07am

Most media put "massive" in quotes, like I just did there.

BornCynic Morning
BE11:08am

Is it a bit showbiz from the regulator to throw around words like that? Particularly as, in terms of punishment for a "massive" fraud, it's pretty small.

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Theranos and Holmes have agreed to settle the fraud charges levied against them. Holmes agreed to pay a $500,000 penalty, be barred from serving as an officer or director of a public company for 10 years, return the remaining 18.9 million shares that she obtained during the fraud, and relinquish her voting control of Theranos by converting her super-majority Theranos Class B Common shares to Class A Common shares. Due to the company’s liquidation preference, if Theranos is acquired or is otherwise liquidated, Holmes would not profit from her ownership until – assuming redemption of certain warrants – over $750 million is returned to defrauded investors and other preferred shareholders. The settlements with Theranos and Holmes are subject to court approval. Theranos and Holmes neither admitted nor denied the allegations in the SEC’s complaint. The SEC will litigate its claims against Balwani in federal district court in the Northern District of California.

BE11:08am

Meh.

BornCynic I am right in thinking she just settled and admitted no liability?
wayneJ How much did Holmes take out of Theranos over the yrs (did she cash any shares / share options and salary and benefits)?
BE11:09am

If that's the worst that'll happen, may as well give it a pop. Put some fairy dust on the Powerpoint and head into the funding rounds. Risk-reward seems tilted to the former.

11:09 am
BE11:10am

Anyway.

undefined
BornCynic BE - you're right. Justice was not done.

Oh yeah, there's also this.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 3,759, down 61.5 (-1.61%), High: 3,830, Low: 3,758, Volume: 1.19m

Having got the signal, we spent months talking about the chances of Unilever staying or going. Long enough to get comfortable with the idea.

BE11:12am

So when they announced they were going -- which was always the nailed-on certainty! See yesterday's session -- the uproar is muted.

BE11:13am

Good news management, I guess.

11:13 am

It also means that there's nearly nothing left to say.

Paper Chase As a Unilever hodler I'm flippin' glad about the decision which, as you say, was never in doubt
VV75 why would there be uproar?

Terminating the Stichting structure is probably the most significant news, as it neuters the "protectionism" stuff.

RA morgen
BE11:15am

And in terms of the effect on index trackers, they DGAF. Which is probably the right approach.

11:15 am
BE11:16am

UBS .....

BE11:16am

At 19x 18E PE, UNA trades at a -5% discount to EU Staples (20x). We think today's news will limit downside risk.

BE11:16am

Thumbs up

undefined

PZ Cussons PLC (PZC:LSE): Last: 234.20, down 42.6 (-15.39%), High: 240.60, Low: 199.70, Volume: 1.39m
RA as may approaches, i recommend glencore everyone
11:17 am
BE11:18am

Been lower. Been sub 200p.

BE11:19am

On the back of a not entirely surprising profit warning, blaming UK being rubbish and Nigeria also being rubbish for different reasons.

BornCynic BE - please don't - it is too painful. I give up and am going to buy an ETF.............one of John Lee's favourites as well.
BE11:19am

The theme here is that Cussons set guidance on the idea that they'd have a better second half than the first. And then they didn't.

Playing FTSE PZ Cussons had kind of teed markets up for this in Dec and then again in Jan
11:20 am
BE11:20am

UK consumer sentiment poor, but also de-stocking by retailers at the discount end of the market .....

BE11:20am

..... none of which is a huge surprise.

BE11:21am

What's less expected is the depth of problems in Nigeria

Forester I suspect PZ is the first of quite a few "Profit is likely to be weighted towards H2" disappointments!
Soundbuy The H2 weighting 'copy and paste' for RNSs......zzzzz
11:21 am
BE11:21am

Where we have cost inflation, no wage growth and "intense" competition.

BE11:21am

Those two markets are 80% of Cussons' earnings, to remind.

Playing FTSE H2No
BornCynic Is Lidl / Aldi now in Nigeria...............
BE11:22am

So ... you're looking at forecasts stepping back by 15% or so in near years and 10% or so out to 2020.

PeterC Re: Elizabeth Holmes and Theranos- the polo neck the tip off, Jonathan Price was a sinister Bond villain in one :-)
11:22 am
BE11:22am

The bigger question, though, is what to do with Nigeria?

Miss Piggy @PeterC: and Gandhi?
BE11:24am

Management's reviewing the milk business and rejigging the new products pipeline .... question is whether that's enough.

Soundbuy @PeterC - those cows bothering you again?
BE11:24am

Quick line from Caz.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

With recovery falling short of expectations FY18E PBT is anticipated in the range of £80-85m, vs consensus of £97m. While we had somewhat anticipated a tough year in the UK, we believe the consumer environment in Nigeria will be difficult to turn around in the short term and may require more drastic decisions. We cut our earnings estimates for FY18-20 by 10-15% and reduce our target price accordingly from 310p to 260p. We remain Neutral.

wayneJ Any thoughts on tax implications of the Unilever decision - both corporate tax and the jobs side - even if 100 jobs presumably high paid and likely to drag external jobs with them eg corporate comms, banking etc
BE11:25am

And Investec.

wayneJ Hard to imagine that the investment banking relationship managers for Unilever are not already scouting houses in Holland
BE11:26am

The balance sheet remains strong (we expect net debt/EBITDA of 1.3x by yearend) which protects the group’s dividend paying capability.
It remains difficult to predict the extent/timing of any recovery, especially in Africa, so we remain prudent. We reduce FY19E PBT to £90m from £108.9m and EPS to 15.4p (prev 18.3p). However, the group will be seeking cost reductions across overheads and COGS which could start to contribute next year

11:26 am
undefined
BE11:28am

Otherwise ............ what to cover? Any requests, anyone?

Soundbuy I'm good today....
BE11:29am

Tesco leading us up at this moment, which is on the back of a JP Morgan upgrade.

11:29 am
Tesco PLC (TSCO:LSE): Last: 215.20, up 4.9 (+2.33%), High: 217.20, Low: 213.00, Volume: 18.07m
Paper Chase Any more developments for Conviviality? More out of morbid fascination than anything else.
BE11:30am

They do the "it's X years since we were positive" intro, which is always a good way into the note.

BE11:30am

We turn buyers of Tesco shares for the first time in five years as its cash flow, top line and balance sheet have improved, whilst Booker adds new addressable market potential and strong execution capabilities with Charles Wilson now at the helm. We see Tesco as a visible turnaround with moving parts (eg, new management, access to new markets, synergies, cost savings, legacy assets). Overtime, we believe the market will shift its view on Tesco to capital return from trading stock and its valuation approach to FCF from P/E. Our 265p Dec-18 PT is based on ‘19/20 7% FCF yield (25% implied upside).

Soundbuy Hikma - delayed response/M&A spec/broker notes?
Gross Loydman Anything on Chariot? Spudded Morocco well yesterday, the market went 'meh'...
MonkeyTrader GKN....I know boring.....but did GKN's Chairmann call up his buddy at Airbus to make that statement? They do have historical board relationships after all......
11:31 am
BE11:31am

They like Booker because of Charles Wilson firstly; more than £6bn of revenue capacity secondly; and expansion of the addressable market.

Grouchmonkey Any comment on CINE please? I know it's all pretty irrelevant until we see how the Regal acquisition goes but still...
BE11:31am

[W]e believe the majority of the c£30bn wholesale market is new market for Tesco, including delivery of £19bn, which is experiencing the highest pace of growth within the industry and where Booker has expertise

Hikma Pharmaceuticals PLC (HIK:LSE): Last: 1,080, up 151 (+16.25%), High: 1,089, Low: 960.80, Volume: 1.25m
Soundbuy Smurfit - any further comment re IP or others...
11:34 am
BE11:34am

I believe it's mostly in response to Citi turning positive.

BE11:34am

Their pharma team -- Andrew Baum, Peter Verdult etc -- is very well followed.

BE11:35am

Gist here is that they could more than double, if everything goes right.

Soundbuy Cheers...........
11:35 am
BE11:35am

BE11:36am

You've also got 10-15% short out there.

BE11:37am

Also, people seem to like the new guy.

11:37 am
BE11:38am

Morgan Stanley incoming .....

BE11:38am

We found Siggi Olafsson's first appearance convincing and believe the market will give him the benefit of the doubt on execution (despite mixed execution in the past). Looking to a similar story with Teva (harsh generic pressure, headwinds at large acquisition), new CEO Kare Schultz has launched an ambitious cost cutting program ($3bn on c.$7bn of EBITDA) and partially as a result, Teva shares have re-rated 70% from the trough. We see superficial similarities in both stories and expect more positive investor sentiment to drive share upside in the near term as we hear more from the new CEO. That being said, we are unsure to what extent Hikma can cut costs and continue to see efficiencies as being more long term and COGS-driven.

MonkeyTrader Also GKN management have some serious questions to answer with respect to the break fee structure they agreed to with Dana? Money for nothing if Melrose wins....$40m of money to be precise.
Jimmy horses please Bryce
Forester Is Airbus' statement today a game changer? Not sure why they care if Melrose owns GKN
BE11:39am

Though they're cautious on any term other than short.

11:39 am
BE11:40am

While we view Hikma's guidance as achievable, we see more risk in EBITDA downgrades as opposed to multiple derating. Specifically, we still see some lack of clarity in the Injectables business and believe intensity of competition could drive variance vs guidance. As well, lack of pipeline in 2018 means we will see no meaningful growth. Overall, we see risk skewed firmly to the upside and see near term upside from more positive sentiment, but see no immediate upside in the fundamental story right now, leaving us EW.

undefined
BE11:41am

Sorry @Jimmy, nothing from Shrewdette yet.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

Fingers crossed we'll get an update before midday.

BE11:41am

Conviviality? I guess, if only to reflect on the bizarre events yesterday.

Chuck Norris Shrewdette has done well for me this week
FATDAZ @Grouch monkey if you on today I found that research on the impact of when and who reads the news has on share prices

The £30m tax bill due on March 29th was just the start of it, amazingly.

Jimmy no worries, the market chat will do

Around lunchtime, long-time Convivality backer Old Mutual mentions that it went down from 7% to circa 3% before the suspension.

BE11:45am

Then, just before the close, they cancel the interim divi to rake back £8m.

Grouchmonkey @FD Yes, please
Forester Can we have a list of all Zeus Capitals clients?!?!
FATDAZ @BE given that Nigerian population is forecast to reach 790 million by 2100 demographics should favour incumbents over long term no ?
11:46 am
BE11:46am

All of which follows Tuesday's profit warning warning, which seemed to clarify that the forecasting error wasn't central to the ma-hoosive 20% earnings miss.

BE11:47am

Rather, it was gross margins in the wholesale business (as in Matthew Clark, formerly of Punch Tavs and reversed into in 2015 in a £200m deal).

BE11:48am

(Pre suspension, I think Conviviality was £185m market cap.)

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Shore reckons the new price might be .... well, zero.

BE11:49am

Another day, another update from Conviviality and once again the statement does not make for pleasant reading. The shares were suspended this morning pending an announcement so we wondered if there had been another discovery to impact profitability or whether there was bid interest that might have been leaked ahead of the market opening. We were not expecting the company to state it had found a c£30m payment due to the HMRC on 29 March 2018. This was also in the period since the statement issued yesterday at just after 1pm. This raises all sorts of questions and has caused a short-term funding issue with accountants PwC now engaged to help find a solution. Sadly it is also another huge dent in management credibility. Looking ahead, we now expect the company to be trapped in a vicious cycle that starves the business of much needed cash and we are increasingly
doubtful equity holders will be left with any value. With limited visibility and confidence in our financial expectations, we withdraw our forecasts and put our Hold recommendation under review.

BE11:50am

You'll also notice that EBITDA guidance is all over the shop between Conviviality's various updates.

FATDAZ @grouch monkey https://hbr.org/2016/09/research-how-investors-reading-habits-influence-stock-prices
Grouchmonkey @FD thanks
11:51 am
BE11:51am

Probably best to assume any number coming from the company is wrong, given everything that's happened so far.

BE11:51am

Back to Shore.

BE11:51am

We are surprised the company has retained its net debt guidance for FY2018F of c£150m given the HMRC payment due before the year end and potential for profitability to be lower than expected. The guidance seems to presume that the payment to HMRC was either included in full year budgets but not in short-term cash flow projections or is paid post year end with profitably remaining in the right ball park.

BornCynic @FATDAZ - you been reading the UN population projections as well? To be honest it is more customers but more problems............
11:52 am
BE11:52am

Our concern now is that the business could be trapped in a vicious cash cycle. We expect cash availability to be put under further pressure from the level of cash available from the receivables facility as the banks manage their risk exposure. Suppliers potentially are also likely to be managing their receivables risk via supply on tighter commercials terms and/or lower order sizes. The recent inclement weather conditions may also have resulted in higher levels of stock in the supply chain too, therefore, potentially having an adverse impact on future short-term sales.

simple simon how do you miraculously realise you owe HMRC £30m?
BE11:52am

What an amazing mess. Administration doesn't look implausible.

Zulu1690 The Conviviality CFO Mark Moran (or is it Moron) spent £130,000 buying shares last week!
undefined

undefined

FATDAZ Re UN pop forecasts yes I have lol

Rather thin for interesting news this morning ...... There's plenty of news, but not much that's interesting.

Shrewdette Just sent to you apols. Had sent to PM earlier
BE11:59am

(@Shrewdette: Thumbs up )

Otter Does the NomAd have any responsibility for the kind of things that Conviviality has been disclosing, or are they only involved in dealing with the listing authorities?
11:59 am
BE11:59am

But thankfully, the only thing of any importance whatsoever has happened! Shrewdette's here!

BE11:59am

2 short odds winners yesterday - only muted celebrations!

BE12:00pm

Two winners is more than I've ever had at the nags. As in, ever.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Here we go with day 3. Special mention for Bet365 with their enterprising each-way terms.

BE12:00pm

(Other bookmakers are available.)

BE12:00pm

1:30 Terrefort 2-2 in Britain heavy ground fine 7/2 W. Sky have money back loser offer. Shattered Love 4-5 over fences. 15/2 EW.
2:10. 6place offers around. Forza Milan EW good 3m second latest. Kansas City Chief 18/1 EW landed gamble in Dec at Doncaster, this tougher.
2:50. Ryanair Chase. Un De Sceau 11/10 fav looks very strong - coping with distance on testing ground only question. But I am hoping Cloudy Dream can overcome his 'seconditis' and win but if not will settle for his longer odds 11/1 with Bet365 for 3 places.
3:30 Stayers Hurdle - best race today IMHO - sky pay 4 and 365 go to 6 slightly reduced odds. Sam Spinner 7/2 should prevail, very progressive. Wholestone 18/1 EW has good Cheltenham form. And my 'off the wall' tiny flutter is on Donna's Diamond 50/1 EW.
4:10. King's Socks 2nd in France to Arkle winner Footpad, soft ground a plus 25/2 EW. Guitar Pete won penultimate unseated last time 16/1 EW. Sky pay 6.
4:50 mares hurdle. By all accounts Laurena 8/13 fav wont get beat. Sky offering 9/4 she wins by 3+lengths. but i'm playing Cap Soleill 10/1 EW. Front running Marias Benefit should also go well but ground might not help her 13/2 EW.
5:30 Kim Muir amateur riders chase: Final Nudge placed in Welsh National 16/1 EW. Very First Time disappointed on hat trick bid but can bounce back 18/1 EW.

12:01 pm
BE12:01pm

And good luck to all.

undefined
BE12:02pm

Okay, midday. If you want to know about the million or so broker calls that are moving stuff this morning, go here: https://www.ft.com...-b27e-cc62a39d57a0

BornCynic Thanks for PZ Cussons BE - have a good day.
Grouchmonkey OK, thanks
Blank canvas Thanks for everything. Happy Ides of March to all
12:04 pm
BE12:04pm

In this place, we're done. Thanks for joining, ta for the comments, and have a splendid Thursday.

BE12:04pm

Afternoon all.
